intro: Acaena argentea f. epargyrea, commonly known as silver weed, is a low-growing perennial plant characterized by its silver-gray foliage. It features small, spiny fruits that are often used as a food source for birds and small mammals. The plant thrives in dry, disturbed soils and is native to regions of South America. Its compact growth habit and drought tolerance make it a common weed in arid and semi-arid environments. Botanically, it belongs to the family Rosaceae and is notable for its unique, clustered inflorescences.

This plant is commonly found in temperate climates, often growing in grasslands and open habitats. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to the seasonal variations of its native environment. The species is part of the rose family (Rosaceae) and is known for its silver-green foliage. Its native distribution reflects its historical range across the southern Andes and surrounding areas.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena argentea f. epargyrea was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive silver foliage.
